If youâ€™re a fan of those spontaneous popâ€‘ups you see in Torontoâ€™s Queen Street West or the quirky vibes of Kensington Market, youâ€™ll want to know about Kakao Payâ€™s brandâ€‘new â€œTogether for a Long Timeâ€ popup that just opened up in Seongsuâ€‘dong.

**Whatâ€™s the deal?**
  
Kakao Pay is basically the Korean version of Apple Pay/Google Payâ€”just a mobile payment app thatâ€™s everywhere.

Theyâ€™ve teamed up with a local cafÃ© chain called Torotoro (yes, thatâ€™s the one that makes those fancy latte art â€œkoreanâ€‘styleâ€ coffee drinks that are as Instagramâ€‘ready as a doubleâ€‘double in a Timâ€‘Hortons).

The popup is a temporary joint venture that blends the convenience of Kakao Pay with the cozy, indie cafÃ© atmosphere of Seongsu.

Think of it as a cross between a tech expo and a popâ€‘up coffee shop.

- 

**Location:**
 3â€‘1 Seongdongâ€‘ro, Seongsuâ€‘dong, Seongâ€‘dongâ€‘gu, Seoul (just a few stops from the Seongsu Station on Line 2â€”easy to hop on a train from any part of the city).  
- 

**Hours:**
 10â€¯AM â€“ 10â€¯PM (Monâ€‘Sat).

Closed on Sundays.  
- 

**Duration:**
 The popup is a 3â€‘month run (late April to early July), so youâ€™ve got plenty of time to swing by if youâ€™re in town.

**Cost & Currency**
  
- Entry is freeâ€”just walk in and youâ€™re good to go.  
- Coffee & snacks: Standard menu items range from 4,000 KRW to 6,000 KRW.

Thatâ€™s about $5â€“$7 CAD (exchange rates vary, but thatâ€™s a ballpark).  
- If youâ€™re looking to try the â€œKakao Pay onlyâ€ specials (theyâ€™re basically a discount if you pay with the app), youâ€™ll get about a 10â€“15% saving.

So, roughly $4â€“$6 CAD for a latte.

**Why should we care?**
  
1. 

**Tech + Culture Fusion:**
 For us Canadians who love tech, this is like seeing a Canadian startup show up in a popâ€‘up store in Torontoâ€™s Distillery District.

You get to test out Kakao Payâ€™s features (like QR payments, inâ€‘app ordering) in a realâ€‘world settingâ€”plus, you can see how the app integrates with Korean cafÃ©s.  
2. 

**Local Food & Coffee:**
 Torotoroâ€™s coffee is seriously good.

Their â€œMochi Latteâ€ (a frothy, sweet treat) is a mustâ€‘try.

And the pastriesâ€”think butter croissants with a hint of matchaâ€”are a sweet, buttery nod to our own Canadian bakery culture.  
3. 

**Community Vibe:**
 The popup is all about â€œtogetherness.â€ Theyâ€™ve set up a small communal table where you can meet other travelers, exchange travel hacks, or just chat over a latte.

Itâ€™s a great spot to meet fellow Canadians (and other expats) who might be in Seoul for the same reasons you areâ€”study, work, or just exploring.

**Insider Tips**
  
- 

**Get There Early:**
 The first week after opening is the busiestâ€”lines can be long, especially for the limitedâ€‘edition coffee.

Arrive around 10â€¯AM or 2â€¯PM to beat the crowds.  
- 

**Use Kakao Pay:**
 If youâ€™re not already a Kakao Pay user, download the app and link it to your Korean bank account (or a local credit card).

Youâ€™ll get a small welcome discount thatâ€™s worth the extra step.  
- 

**Bring a Friend:**

Itâ€™s a fun way to share the experience and save a bit.
